comments.commentBody: Hmmm.. Anyone want to wager if UPS and FEDEX are also involved in these shenanigans ?
Exactly, my sentiments. I was surprised at the note in the back of my po box that I mentioned in my comment, however.

So the postman read your mail to sort and deliver it, and then never saw it again, or remembered it.

Now the NSA keeps records of you and your correspondence and correspondents. For a dossier on all of you.

And you think that's the same.

Uncomprehending innocence is really no defense.

I think most of the comments to this article are overblown.
It's been my expectation that my delivery mailman has been reading the outside of my mail for the past 75 years, and that my local postal branch have been doing likewise when they sorted it, and my outgoing mail. Our local branch is operated completely manually, and I've never given a thought to expecting privacy for the data on the outside of mail.
I must admit, I do keep my postcard language polite, but maybe that's because I value my reputation, and the fact that my friend's children my be retrieving the mail.
I wonder if UPS and FedEx are also giving this type of information to the government.

The ACA was actually quite brilliantly designed, GIVEN THE POLITICAL REALITIES that exist after decades of Republican and AMA demonization of "socialized medicine," that has prevented the U.S. from adopting a more efficient and effective system like those enjoyed by other advanced countries.

It is a HUGE accomplishment to actually at least have a foot in the door for the beginnings of reform.

Personally, I would much prefer single payer (e.g., like Medicare that the Canadians extend to the entire population) or government operated (like the British system and the VA). But the ACA, instead of getting rid of the private insurance industry, regulates it, requires that it's overhead and profits are limited to a lower percentage of the premiums than they are now charging, etc.

Certainly, the ACA needs further refinement, if not complete overhaul. But people should not underestimate the value of having at least a start on reining in the massive rip-off of the population by the unregulated medical-industrial complex--while lower income Americans are left without insurance and without decent health care.

The imprecision of this piece is troubling on a number of levels. Is the author concerned with the possible improved productivity of mentally ill employees, or the assumed increased creativity/intellectual attainments of these presumed "mad geniuses?' She invokes an old and treasured myth; that people with mental illness are somehow endowed with enhanced creative or intellectual powers, as if that is proof of something, but neglects the fact that we notice what is novel, not what is commonplace. The myth has been venerated but not empirically validated.

Mental illness is not a single monolithic entity but rather a number of different illnesses with, sometimes, overlapping symptoms. However, the author seems to lump a variety of different illness, including unspecified neurological disorders, together as one. That's wrong. How were any of these conditions, such as the ADHD, diagnosed? Is a "little bit" of OCD actually OCPD, a personality disorder, or is it the debilitating and disruptive OCD? And is a 48 hour coding session truly an indication of a manic state or something else entirely?

Mental illness unquestionably does more harm than good, although some people are able to achieve remarkable things despite their illness, rather than because of it. This confused, simplistic piece, however, does a disservice to those who struggle with mental illness, whether successfully, or less so, and seems to make light of the potential severity of this group of illnesses.

The importance of Little Round Top to the success of the ANV at Gettysburg is a myth.  It was a defensive position, not suited for offensive or an artillery platform.  The opportunity to roll up Meade's left flank was below Little Round Top and into The Wheatfield...
No disrespect intended, but it is good to read about someone other than the 20th Maine.  Ken Burns has done enough for them.  Hooray for the 2d Wisconsin

There were a host of courageous acts at Gettysburg that played a crucial role in bringing victory to the Union. The 20th Maine's defense of Little Roundtop was another one of these, because if the Southerners had taken Little Roundtop on the Union's left flank, they could have conceivable rolled up the Union line and drove the Union Army from their advantageous position on the high ground. Col. Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain's men expended virtually all of their ammunition defending Little Roundtop against a determined group of Alabamans from Longstreet's Corps. They then fixed bayonets and charged down the hill, surprising the Alabamans and forcing their surrender.

The defense of Culps Hill on the Union right was also heroic and prevented the rebels from overrunning the Baltimore Pike and the Union supply line. Outnumbered Yankees fought the confederates from behind log barricades and from dug out trenches. The rebs came within an eyelash of overrunning the Union positions.

I've been a psychiatrist for 40+ years and, Tim, you've misdiagnosed our country. Schizophrenia, paranoid or otherwise, doesn't fit at all.

The following symptoms define Narcissistic Personality Disorder. Think maybe some of these fit the U.S. of A.? (I don't think 'lack of empathy' describes most Americans however. Mainly our congressional folks. Speaking of empathy, Nicolas Kristof is about as empathic as a person can be. And I don't even know him.)

1) An exaggerated sense of one's own abilities and achievements.

2) A constant need for attention, affirmation and praise.

3) A belief that he or she is unique or "special" and should only associate with other people of the same status.

4) Persistent fantasies about attaining success and power.

5) Exploiting other people for personal gain.

6) A sense of entitlement and expectation of special treatment.

7) A preoccupation with power or success.

8) Feeling envious of others, or believing that others are envious of him or her.

9) A lack of empathy for others.

"Societies are healthier when most economic activity is mostly local--when people buy from and sell to their neighbors,"

"With increased globalization, economic activity undermines social bonds and leads to isolation and alienation."

If a factory closes up and moves to China, that means social bonds are undermined and the people living in the area become isolated and alienated? How do you figure that?

Capital always migrates to where the labor is cheapest.

So now the capitalists have fled the nations where capitalism developed, and we are left with the same forces working against us that those nations inflicted upon the places they colonized.

Societies are healthier when most economic activity is mostly local--when people buy from and sell to their neighbors, so that economic ties reinforce social bonds. With increased globalization, economic activity undermines social bonds and leads to isolation and alienation. People may be richer in currency (some of them, anyway) but overall, their lives are poorer.

Of course, there are all the preparations for a trip--packing the right clothing and equipment, reading up on the area, making sure each family member packs things to occupy down time. When they are young, this involves a parent's bag of tricks containing new books, toys, activities, and treats.

Our vacations were often traveling to visit grandparents or other family a thousand or more miles away. But whether they were the family kind or "real" vacations, of which we had a few too, the essential thing was to be sure to build in activities that would specifically appeal to each member of the family. When the kids were little they might both like the same thing--we've been to all the major zoos in Ohio and in a number of other cities. But when they got older they of course had their own preferences.

For instance, for our trip to Belize when they were teenagers we went on several birding trips for my husband, climbed the ruins in Tikal and elsewhere for me, snorkeled and swam with rays and sharks for our daughter, and went scuba diving for our son. Of course we all enjoyed those and other activities (there's a zoo!), but each of us had his/her favorites.
